tn.text: Parallelism is common in Hebrew poetry. (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:writing_poetry]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])
"This is for the director of music to use in worship"
This may refer to a style of music.
Possible meanings are 1) David wrote the psalm or 2) the psalm is about David or 3) the psalm is in the style of David's psalms.

tn.ref: how magnificent is your name in all the earth
tn.text: God's "name" represents his whole being. AT: "people all over the world know that you are very great" (UDB) (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: Out of the mouth of babies and infants you have created praise
tn.text: Causing babies to praise God is spoken of as if the praise were an object that God created in the babies' mouths and made come out. AT: "You have given babies and infants the ability to praise you" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]])

tn.ref: your heavens, which your fingers have made
tn.text: God's fingers represent him. AT: "the heavens which you have made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_synecdoche]])

tn.ref: Of what importance is the human race that you notice them, or mankind that you pay attention to them?
tn.text: These remarks have been expressed in the form of a question to add emphasis. AT: "It is amazing that you think about people and are concerned about them!" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_rquestion]])
Both of these phrases refer to people in general.

tn.ref: have crowned them with glory and honor
tn.text: Glory and honor are spoken of as if they were crowns. The words "glory" and "honor" are similar in meaning.  AT: "have given them glory and honor" or "have caused them to be like kings" (See: [[:en:ta:vol1:translate:figs_metaphor]] and [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_doublet]])

tn.ref: You make him to rule over the works ... you have put all things under his feet
tn.text: These two clauses express similar meanings.  (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_parallelism]])

tn.ref: You make him ... under his feet
tn.text: "you make them ... under their feet." The words "him" and "his" here refer to people.
The hands represent what God has done. AT: "the things that you made" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: you have put all things under his feet
tn.text: Having authority to rule others or control things is spoken of as having those things under one's feet. This means God gave people authority over all creation. AT: "you have given him authority over all things" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])

tn.ref: how magnificent is your name in all the earth
tn.text: With this exclamation, David shows his joy and awe about how great God is. AT: "your name is wonderfully magnificent in all the earth" or "people in all the earth know how magnificent you are" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_exclamations]])
God's "name" represents him or his reputation. AT: "your reputation" (See: [[:en:ta:vol2:translate:figs_metonymy]])
